ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a more conversational set of Hebrew words - words that would be helpful to navigating a summer/year in Israel.
Hebrew speaking skills, researching things in Hebrew online
I gained a greater confidence in my ability to carry on extended conversations in Modern Hebrew, as well as expanding my vocabulary and my fluency.
I learned how to better my Hebrew and speak as a native speaker. I got the opportunity to learn crucial skills that I will need if I were to live in Israel.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great course - loved the material selection. At times there was a lot of work.

This was a really engaging class with a lot of interesting material covered. Highlights for me were the weekly conversation sessions outside of class, the two cooking workshops where we prepared authentic Israeli dishes, and the assignments that required us to use real life Israeli websites to complete tasks or find information.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to anyone who is at L4/L5 level in Hebrew, especially if spoken Hebrew is your least confident area. Although it will feel like a lot (especially the high number of recording assignments, which really put you outside your comfort zone) at the end you will be surprised at how much more freely you can carry on a conversation.
I absolutely would recommend this course to another student.
